metadata.paragraph_text_preview: This case is about New York’s deadline for independent nominating petitions, which must be filed 23 ...

target:
This case is about New York’s deadline for independent nominating petitions, which must be filed 23 weeks before the general election. Byron W. Brown was the incumbent Mayor of Buffalo but lost the June 22, 2021 Democratic primary election. Two months later, Brown filed an independent nominating petition seeking to appear on the general election ballot. That petition was rejected because it was filed after the deadline of May 25, 2021.

On August 30, 2021, three registered voters who supported Byron W. Brown’s independent candidacy for Mayor filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York. They sued the Erie County Board of Elections under 42 U.S.C. § 1983. Represented by private counsel, the plaintiffs sought 1) a declaratory judgment that New York’s deadline for independent candidate petitions as applied to Byron W. Brown for Mayor of Buffalo violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution; 2) an order enjoining the Board from enforcing the deadline and from failing to place him on the 2021 general-election ballot; and 3) attorneys’ fees. The case was assigned to District Judge John Sinatra, Jr.

On September 3, 2021, the district court issued a preliminary injunction ordering the Erie County Board of Elections to put Byron W. Brown on the 2021 ballot as an independent candidate for Mayor of Buffalo. The defendants appealed that injunction to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, which issued an order on September 16, 2021 staying of the preliminary injunction. The plaintiffs did not appeal the Second Circuit’s order, and Byron W. Brown did not appear on the general election ballot. However, on November 2, 2021, Brown won reelection after campaigning as a write-in candidate.

Brown’s election victory rendered the appeal of the district court’s preliminary injunction moot, so the Second Circuit sent the case back to the district court to hear the plaintiff’s constitutional challenge to the independent nominating petition deadline. On April 20, 2022, the district court referred the case to U.S. Magistrate Judge Michael Roemer.

On July 11, 2023, the district court ruled that despite the 2021 election having already taken place and Brown winning reelection, the constitutional challenge was not moot because the underlying dispute was capable of repetition, yet evading review. However, the court dismissed the complaint because it found that the independent petition deadline did not violate the plaintiffs’ constitutional rights.

On August 19, 2024, the Second Circuit vacated the district court’s July 11, 2023 order. The Second Circuit sent the case back to the district court with instructions to dismiss the case as moot. The Second Circuit expressed no view on the constitutionality of the challenged filing deadline. On August 20, 2024, the district court dismissed the case as moot.

On June 2, 2025, the U.S. Supreme Court decided not to hear the case.
target_paragraph: This case is about New York’s deadline for independent nominating petitions, which must be filed 23 weeks before the general election. Byron W. Brown was the incumbent Mayor of Buffalo but lost the June 22, 2021 Democratic primary election. Two months later, Brown filed an independent nominating petition seeking to appear on the general election ballot. That petition was rejected because it was filed after the deadline of May 25, 2021.

annotation.explanation: 23 weeks before the general election: New York’s deadline by which independent nominating petitions must be filed.

The case involves New York’s 23-week pre–general election deadline for independent nominating petitions and Byron W. Brown’s late filing after losing the June 22, 2021 Democratic primary; his petition, filed two months later and after the May 25, 2021 deadline, was rejected.
